title: Guide: Important Things About Working With Sourdough
intro: These are handy informations about anything related to sourdoughs
content: /p;I've been thinking on creating an easily available info page about anything related to sourdoughs in one article, because searching multiple articles to get some forgotten infos can kinda can get under one's skin. But what is a sourdough though, and why should I need one?

/p;Well a sourdough starter is made up by combining water and flour into eachother. The magic starts when we expose this combination to air, which populates the starter with good bacteria and forming an entire ecosystem inside this dough. 2 of the most essential bacteria we always find in a starter are lactic acid bacteria (LAB) and wild yeasts, which break down carbohydrates and produces gas as a result, which is the primary reason our dough can rise.
/h2;Starter maintaining
/p;Your starter needs to be refed on certain occasions, because it won't be able to produce any rises or in the worst case scenario, the starter can even die out from malnourishment.
/p;There are 2 methods to store your starter which heavily alters the frequeny of the feeding sessions (Please choose the fridge option stg):
/ul
/s;Stored in fridge: ;Feed it every week. Can be saved if exactly 2 weeks have passed by feeding it once and another time tomorrow
/s;Stored in room temperature area: ;Feed it daily twice. You need be a psychopath to choose this option
//ul

/p;In all cases a starter is advised to be fed with greater amounts on fewer occasions, rather than with light amounts on many occasions. The reason is because you won't see an active enough starter if you don't feed it with enough flour and water.

/p;In terms of feeding ratios, most people usually go with a 1:1:1 ratio, which means for 1g of starter, 1g of flour and water will be added into the mix. You can go with a higher ratio as well, where the only difference is that the duration of the starter rising will be noticeably higher, although I would recommend going at max with a 1:4:4 ratio.

/p;But also do we really need to strictly stay with a 50% flour and 50% water combination? Well I've good news for you because you surely can! Straying away from the default 100% hydration (1g water for 1g flour) level changes the feeding frequency need, mixing difficulty and sourness taste. Personally speaking, I've only used 80% hydration starters and there was no issue with mixing the ingredients for me.
/ul

/s;Lower hydration (<100%): ;Can go longer without feedings, because the wild yeast and LAB can't consume as fast due to the water shortage. Harder to mix. Produces a more sour flavor because there will be more lactic acid generation happening in the starter.
/s;Higher hydration (>100%): ;Needs more feedings, because they feed quicker due to the higher amount of water. Easier to mix. Has a milder sour flavor.
//ul

/p;After you've succesfully selected the most comfy ratio and mixed them together, then you should leave the starter to rest on your counter exposed to open air for 2 hours, and after that just store it in a preferred place (pwease let it be fridge, pwetty pwease) with the lid completely sealed off for overnight.
/h2;Converting yeasted recipes to sourdough
/p;Often times bakers wish to use their favorite recipe or were only able to find a non-sourdough one. Luckily altering the recipe is possible with some basic maths.
/p;In a conversion scenario 100g starter equals with 7g of dried yeast, which means 1g yeast ~= 14g of starter
/p/s;The yeasted (yuckyyy) recipe:
/ul
;500g flour
;7g yeast
;350g water
;10g salt
//ul
/p/s;Converted with 100% hydration starter:
/ul
;10g salt
//ul
/p/s;Converted with 80% hydration starter:
/ul
;10g salt
//ul
/h2;General tips about using the starter in a recipe

/p;Whenever you're planning to work with a sourdough recipe, I would recommend in the first steps to mix the required starter amount with lukewarm water. It will only deconstruct itself into some smaller chunks, but that's perfectly enough. After this preliminary step, you can just continue with the required instructions found in the recipe.
/p;You can also change the amount of starter you wish to add, the deviations of which you can see here:
/p/s;Less starter:
/ul
;Longer fermentation (more waiting)
;Will result in a more sour-flavored dough
;Increased hydration level (except for recipes with hydration higher than the starter)
//ul
/p/s;More starter:
/ul
;Faster fermentation (less waiting)
;Will result in a milder sour-flavored dough
;Lower hydration level
//ul

/p;Usually it's a common practice to knead the doughs until they have completely formed without stickiness in one go when we're using yeasted recipes, which isn't to say that kneading can't be done while working with a sourdough, but in a lot of cases using a no-knead method makes life noticeably more hassle-free.
/p;The steps go like this:
/ol
;Mix the dough ingredients until they have just formed into eachother. This usually takes 1-2 minutes
;Cover it with a blanket and let it rest for 15-30 minutes
;Sprinkle your hand with some water, because the dough will be really sticky. ;/a;https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QYzxulQY1Gc;Fold it from 4 sides like in this video;
;Rest it covered with your blanket for 20-30 mins
;Repeat step 3, until you have made 4 fold session in total
//ol
/p;This process is used for introducing some air into the dough, which will create air bubbled, and developing the gluten molecule network which will make the dough less sticky and more stretchable.

/p;Most of the time we usually do cold fermentation after the folding has been done, and possible other steps after that. Cold fermentation means that we put it in the fridge to rest and develop it's flavors + letting it rise. It's advisable to rest it for atleast overnight and possibly maximum 3 days, because we can overferment the dough as well.
/p;These are all the general tips I have in my mind which are good to know currently. This page will possibly be heavily edited.

sources.title: 6 Basic Sourdough Kneading Techniques
Sourdough Fermentation Process – How Does It All Work?
The Ultimate Sourdough Starter Guide
Így számold át az élesztős recepteket kovászosra

title: Setting up Jellyfin on k3s in Rocky Linux
intro: This is part 1 of the *arr stack guide
content: /p;My walkthrough will present a simple Jellyfin setup with a 1 node cluster, with some additional solutions to problems I have faced, which may or may not help you.
/h2;Installing & configuring k3s

/p;Before you plan to ctrl+c and ctrl+v my code snippets, k3s should be properly installed and configured. Don't worry the code consists of one line only, although installing via curl is definitely a blasphemy to some people.
/c;curl -sfL https://get.k3s.io | sh -

/p/s;(OPTIONAL): ;If you perhaps are wishing to run a multi node cluster, then you also need to install k3s on those other nodes, and append them to the cluster. I haven't dwelved myself in this area, so you are left to your own devices.
/c;curl -sfL https://get.k3s.io | K3S_URL=https://myserver:6443 K3S_TOKEN=mynodetoken sh -

/p;More than likely if you use an RHEL-based system such as Rocky, you will experience the benefits and drawbacks of SELinux. SELinux is a security enchancement program to Linux which restricts applications access to certain actions and directories. If you have SELinux enabled, then you will sure experience issues related to directories.

/p;In order to solve this you need to start k3s with 'SELinux Enforcement' turned on. You can just include an additional --selinux flag when starting k3s, but for consistency I prefer to customize the k3s configuration file.

/p;Open or create this config file in path /etc/rancher/k3s/config.yaml with your preferred editor and include this line in the file. (Don't worry if config.yaml doesn't exist for you, it didn't exist for me either)
/c;selinux: true
/h2;Explaining Deployment, Service and Ingress
/p;Just skip this section if you already know about these terms.

/p/s;Deployment: ; It's where we specify which container image to download, the number of replicas it should produce, volumes, environment variables, and so on. Basically, it's like a Dockerfile with some additional options.
/p/s;Service :; This is basically a static floating IP (IP address never changes) which forwards the incoming request from the Ingress to one of the pods in said deployment.

/p;Why do we need this tho? Well pods on a deployment are ephemeral, which means that they usually die out for whatever reason, and usually a new pod is created upon this news to replace the missing pod, The 1 main side effect with this approach is that these pods don't have a stable IP, so if a pod uses 192.168.1.10 as an IP and it gets replaced with a new pod, then that new pod may have a differenet IP address, for example 192.168.1.12. In this case relying upon the pods IP address as the direction is flawed. Using the Service, however, provides us with a stable IP, which detects the correct pods by their assigned labels to send the request to. Service also does load balancing, loose coupling and other handy stuffs.

/p/s;Ingress :; Ingress is our load balancer and proxy which faces the internet / users, which will forward the request towards our Service object. We can and will define domain addresses (ex: hello.mydomain.com) where if we or our users access said domain, then the forwarding will start.

/b64;data:image/png;base64,
/h2;Jellyfin setup

/p;As a start, we should define how our Jellyfin deployment should look. I'm going to elaborate some lines in this yaml configuration in next of these comments to have a slightly better understading of these lines' purposes.
/ul
/s;metadata: ;We define the deployment's name with 'name' which can be seen with a 'kubectl get deployments' command

/s;selector matchLabels VS template labels: ;Template labels are used for applying labels to the deployable pods in the deployment. On the other hand, the selector matchLabels is used for helping kubernetes on which type of pods it should manage (ex: checking if enough replica pods are running). You may think that the selector labels is just an unnecessary complexity to the configuration, and you're exactly right. Probably it has some edge use case for it for not having this pod label assumption be on by default.

/s;PUID and PGID: You might encounter permission related issues, like not being able to write into a mounted volume, or getting a Bad Gateway issue when trying to reach Jellyfin, which also could be related to a permission issue. The ID 1000 is usually the first user of Linux system, which you most likely created while installing a Linux based OS.
/s;volumeMounts and volumes: ;volumeMounts is the path / volume INSIDE the container, while volumes is claiming a volume, which is on the node
//ul

/c;apiVersion: apps/v1
kind: Deployment
metadata:
  name: jellyfin-deployment
  labels:   # Define labels to refer to this exact deployment
    app: jellyfin
spec:
  replicas: 1   # Amount of pods to be present
  selector:
    matchLabels:    # Define which labelled pods to manage
      app: jellyfin
  template:
    metadata:
      labels:   # Apply labels to deployed pods
        app: jellyfin
    spec:
      containers:
      - name: jellyfin
        image: linuxserver/jellyfin:10.10.7
        env:
          - name: TZ
            value: "Etc/UTC"    # Set timezone
          - name: PUID
            value: "1000"       # PUID and PGID are needed for permission issues
          - name: PGID
            value: "1000"
        ports:
        - containerPort: 8096
        volumeMounts:
          - name: config    # Path to config inside the container
            mountPath: /config
          - name: tvseries  # Path to tvseries inside the container
            mountPath: /data/tvseries
          - name: movies    # Path to movies inside the container
            mountPath: /data/movies
      volumes:
        - name: config  # Select the volume claim and attach it to config path
          persistentVolumeClaim:
            claimName: jellyfin-config-pvc
        - name: tvseries    # Select the volume claim and attach it to tvseries path
          persistentVolumeClaim:
            claimName: tvseries-pvc
        - name: movies  # Select the volume claim and attach it to movies path
          persistentVolumeClaim:
            claimName: movies-pvc
/p;Jellyfin Service is a considerably smaller config file

/c;apiVersion: v1
kind: Service
metadata:
  name: jellyfin-service
spec:
  selector:
    app: jellyfin  # Which pod to forward the request to
  ports:
    - protocol: TCP
      port: 8096  # Port of this service
      targetPort: 8096  # Which port of the target pod forward the request to
/p;The Ingress configuration runs on Traefik, since that one is the default on k3s
/ul

/s;annotations: ;Annotations can be used on Service and Ingress configurations. In our case, annotations can tweak the requests coming to Ingress, like only accepting certain entrypoints (ex: only HTTP/2 and HTTP/3), ignoring HTTP only requests and so on. For us, we use a middleware. which modifies the request's content.

/s;rules: ;This is where we can select on which domains we will listen for requests. In this case we listen on domain.com's domains ALL paths. This means we accept domain.com/. domain.com/insert-path, domain.com/insert-path/insert-path2, and so on.
//ul

/c;apiVersion: networking.k8s.io/v1
kind: Ingress
metadata:
  name: ingress
  annotations:
    traefik.ingress.kubernetes.io/router.middlewares: default-content-type-options@kubernetescrd
spec:
  rules:
  - host: "domain.com"  # Listen to this address
    http:
      paths:
      - pathType: Prefix
        path: "/"
        backend:
          service:
            name: jellyfin-service  # Which service to forward the request to
            port:
              number: 8096  # Which port of the service to forward this request to
/p;Volumes
/ul

/s;storageClassName: ;Optionally you can define what kinda of 'class' / type this storage is by defining a storage class configuration. For example you could make a storage class which is a Google Cloud class of volume. I didn't define this file, and idk why is this present in my config tbf
/s;capacity: ;Set the size of the storage
/s;accessModes: ;There are multiple accessModes which decide how many pods can interact with said volume on XY nodes. In ReadWriteOnce's case, only one pod has access to the volume
/s;hostPath: ;The path on where to store this volume. As a mention, using hostPath isn't recommended for a multi-node cluster.
//ul

/c;apiVersion: v1
kind: PersistentVolume
metadata:
  name: jellyfin-config-pv  # Name of the volume
spec:
  storageClassName: local-storage  # This is probably not needed
  capacity:
    storage: 1Gi  # Size of storage
  accessModes:
    - ReadWriteOnce  # Only one pod can have access to this volume at the same time
  hostPath:
    path: /pool/filesystem/jellyfin/library  # Volume's location
---
apiVersion: v1
kind: PersistentVolume
metadata:
  name: tvseries-pv
spec:
  storageClassName: local-storage
  capacity:
    storage: 1T
  accessModes:
    - ReadWriteMany  # Multiple pods can have access to this volume at the same time
  hostPath:
    path: /pool/filesystem/tvseries
---
apiVersion: v1
kind: PersistentVolume
metadata:
  name: movies-pv
spec:
  storageClassName: local-storage
  capacity:
    storage: 1T
  accessModes:
    - ReadWriteMany  # Multiple pods can have access to this volume at the same time
  hostPath:
    path: /pool/filesystem/movies
/p;Volume claims is really similar in structure compared to volumes, where we define the criterias to select our desired volume, such as accessModes, storage size and so on

/c;apiVersion: v1
kind: PersistentVolumeClaim
metadata:
  name: jellyfin-config-pvc
spec:
  storageClassName: local-storage
  accessModes:
    - ReadWriteOnce
  resources:
    requests:
      storage: 1Gi  # What should be the size of the volume
  volumeName: jellyfin-config-pv  # Which volume we want to claim
---
apiVersion: v1
kind: PersistentVolumeClaim
metadata:
  name: movies-pvc
spec:
  storageClassName: local-storage
  accessModes:
    - ReadWriteMany
  resources:
    requests:
      storage: 1T
  volumeName: movies-pv
---
apiVersion: v1
kind: PersistentVolumeClaim
metadata:
  name: tvseries-pvc
spec:
  storageClassName: local-storage
  accessModes:
    - ReadWriteMany
  resources:
    requests:
      storage: 1T
  volumeName: tvseries-pv
/h2;Configuring Jellyfin

/p;I would usually recommend following the official guide (https://jellyfin.org/docs/general/post-install/setup-wizard) or watching a video about it, however there are some recommended extra configurations as well
/p/s;Using hardware acceleration: I haven't done this step myself, but this is where you should look (https://jellyfin.org/docs/general/post-install/transcoding/hardware-acceleration/)
/p/s;Creating new users: You can set new users in the Dashboard -> Users page

/p/s;Adding plugins: You can add some extra features in Dashboard -> Plugins -> Catalog, but I mostly add new metadata plugins such as AniSearch, which can be ticked in the previously created media libraries to have a better hit chance on grabbing infos from a said series / movie.
/p;Good luck on your journey, fellow traveler. I hope my humble guide helps you out on your adventure ^^

sources.title: Kubernetes Documentation
Understanding Storage Classes and Dynamic Provisioning in Kubernetes
Kubernetes Storage: PV, PVC and Storage Class
TechWorld with Nana
DevOps Toolkit
Kubernetes Persistent Volume (PV) and Persistent Volume Claim (PVC)

title: Setting up Radarr + Sonarr on k3s in Rocky Linux
intro: This is part 2 of the *arr stack guide
content: /p;PART 1 OF THIS GUIDE IS MANDATORY

/p;This is the continuation of my quest in building a full *arr stack (Jellyfin, Jellyseerr, Radarr, Sonarr, Prowlarr, Qbittorrent) with k3s (for funsies) in order for my parents not renting out movies from goddamn Telekom.
/p;If you wish to gain some basic understandement on what each of these files are for, then check out the part 1, aka the 'Setting up Jellyfin on k3s in Rocky Linux' article.
/h2;Radarr and Sonarr setup

/p;Since I will show both Radarr and Sonarr, you will see 2 deployment, service and other files in each code segments. Mostly speaking you won't see that much of a difference compared to the part 1 of my article. The main difference is that we are downloading either Radarr or Sonarr.

/p;These are the deployment configuration, which will assemble the pod. The main notable difference compared to Jellyfin is that these deployments require a 'downloads' volume. This is where the requested media will be downloaded into.

/c;apiVersion: apps/v1
kind: Deployment
metadata:
  name: radarr-deployment
  labels:   # Define labels to refer to this exact deployment
    app: radarr
spec:
  replicas: 1   # Amount of pods to be present
  selector:
    matchLabels:    # Define which labelled pods to manage
      app: radarr
  template:
    metadata:
      labels:   # Apply labels to deployed pods
        app: radarr
    spec:
      containers:
      - name: radarr
        image: linuxserver/radarr:5.21.1
        env:
          - name: TZ
            value: "Etc/UTC"
          - name: PUID
            value: "1000"   # PUID and PGID are needed for permission issues
          - name: GUID
            value: "1000"
        ports:
        - containerPort: 7878
        volumeMounts:       # Path to folders inside the container
          - name: config
            mountPath: /config
          - name: movies
            mountPath: /movies
          - name: downloads
            mountPath: /downloads
      volumes:              # Select the volume claims and attach it to their corresponding path
        - name: config
          persistentVolumeClaim:
            claimName: radarr-config-pvc
        - name: movies
          persistentVolumeClaim:
            claimName: movies-pvc
        - name: downloads
          persistentVolumeClaim:
            claimName: downloads-pvc
---
apiVersion: apps/v1
kind: Deployment
metadata:
  name: sonarr-deployment
  labels:
    app: sonarr
spec:
  replicas: 1
  selector:
    matchLabels:
      app: sonarr
  template:
    metadata:
      labels:
        app: sonarr
    spec:
      containers:
      - name: sonarr
        image: linuxserver/sonarr:4.0.14
        env:
          - name: TZ
            value: "Etc/UTC"
          - name: PUID
            value: "1000"
          - name: GUID
            value: "1000"
        ports:
        - containerPort: 8989
        volumeMounts:
          - name: config
            mountPath: /config
          - name: tvseries
            mountPath: /tvseries
          - name: downloads
            mountPath: /downloads
      volumes:
        - name: config
          persistentVolumeClaim:
            claimName: sonarr-config-pvc
        - name: tvseries
          persistentVolumeClaim:
            claimName: tvseries-pvc
        - name: downloads
          persistentVolumeClaim:
            claimName: downloads-pvc
/p;And these are the service configurations, needed for reaching the deployments, AKA the Radarr and Sonarr pods.

/c;apiVersion: v1
kind: Service
metadata:
  name: radarr-service
spec:
  selector:
    app: radarr
  ports:
    - protocol: TCP
      port: 7878
      targetPort: 7878
---
apiVersion: v1
kind: Service
metadata:
  name: sonarr-service
spec:
  selector:
    app: sonarr
  ports:
    - protocol: TCP
      port: 8989
      targetPort: 8989

/p;Here are the volumes which are needed to make Sonarr and Radarr work. Do note that a 'movies' volume already has been created in the part 1 of this guide, so we only need to create a Radarr and Sonarr specific config volume and a 'downloads' volume where the movies and series will be downloaded.

/c;apiVersion: v1
kind: PersistentVolumeClaim
metadata:
  name: radarr-config-pvc
spec:
  storageClassName: local-storage
  accessModes:
    - ReadWriteOnce
  resources:
    requests:
      storage: 1Gi
  volumeName: radarr-config-pv
---
apiVersion: v1
kind: PersistentVolumeClaim
metadata:
  name: sonarr-config-pvc
spec:
  storageClassName: local-storage
  accessModes:
    - ReadWriteOnce
  resources:
    requests:
      storage: 1Gi
  volumeName: sonarr-config-pv
---
apiVersion: v1
kind: PersistentVolumeClaim
metadata:
  name: downloads-pvc
spec:
  storageClassName: local-storage
  accessModes:
    - ReadWriteMany
  resources:
    requests:
      storage: 500Gi
  volumeName: downloads-pv

/c;apiVersion: v1
kind: PersistentVolume
metadata:
  name: radarr-config-pv
spec:
  storageClassName: local-storage
  capacity:
    storage: 1Gi
  accessModes:
    - ReadWriteOnce
  hostPath:
    path: /pool/filesystem/radarr/data
---
apiVersion: v1
kind: PersistentVolume
metadata:
  name: sonarr-config-pv
spec:
  storageClassName: local-storage
  capacity:
    storage: 1Gi
  accessModes:
    - ReadWriteOnce
  hostPath:
    path: /pool/filesystem/sonarr/data
---
apiVersion: v1
kind: PersistentVolume
metadata:
  name: downloads-pv
spec:
  storageClassName: local-storage
  capacity:
    storage: 500Gi
  accessModes:
    - ReadWriteMany
  hostPath:
    path: /pool/filesystem/downloads
/p;The ingress configuration was just appended with 2 new domains, which forward to the Radarr and Sonarr deployments.

/c;---
apiVersion: networking.k8s.io/v1
kind: Ingress
metadata:
  name: ingress
  annotations:
    traefik.ingress.kubernetes.io/router.middlewares: default-content-type-options@kubernetescrd
spec:
  rules:
    - host: jellyfin.domain.xyz
      http:
        paths:
          - pathType: Prefix
            path: /
            backend:
              service:
                name: jellyfin-service
                port:
                  number: 8096
    - host: radarr.domain.xyz
      http:
        paths:
          - pathType: Prefix
            path: /
            backend:
              service:
                name: radarr-service
                port:
                  number: 7878
    - host: sonarr.domain.xyz
      http:
        paths:
          - pathType: Prefix
            path: /
            backend:
              service:
                name: sonarr-service
                port:
                  number: 8989
/p;Good luck with configuring Radarr and Sonarr up. They can be finnicky sometimes :D
/h2;Useful fixes for configuration issues
/ul

/s;Nyaa.si results don't show up when searching on Radarr: ;This is a compatiblity issue with nyaa.si, which can be resolved if you had setup the indexers with Prowlarr. In Prowlarr, edit the nyaa.si indexer, and in it's settings turn on 'Improve Radarr compatibility by removing year information from keywords and adding it to Release Titles' option.
//ul

sources.title: Kubernetes Documentation
Understanding Storage Classes and Dynamic Provisioning in Kubernetes
Kubernetes Storage: PV, PVC and Storage Class
TechWorld with Nana
DevOps Toolkit
Kubernetes Persistent Volume (PV) and Persistent Volume Claim (PVC)

title: Setting up Prowlarr on k3s in Rocky Linux
intro: This is part 3 of the *arr stack guide
content: /p;PART 1,2 OF THIS GUIDE IS MANDATORY

/p;This is the continuation of my quest in building a full *arr stack (Jellyfin, Jellyseerr, Radarr, Sonarr, Prowlarr, Qbittorrent) with k3s (for funsies) in order for my parents not renting out movies from goddamn Telekom.
/p;If you wish to gain some basic understandement on what each of these files are for, then check out the part 1, aka the 'Setting up Jellyfin on k3s in Rocky Linux' article.
/h2;Prowlarr setup

/p;Since Prowlarr's aim is to simplify or managament of indexers in different types of media handling programs such as Sonarr (series), Radarr (movies), Readarr (books), Lidarr (music) etc., it only really needs a config volume as a storage, otherwise it looks similar to the previous deployment files.

/c;apiVersion: apps/v1
kind: Deployment
metadata:
  name: prowlarr-deployment
  labels:
    app: prowlarr
spec:
  replicas: 1
  selector:
    matchLabels:
      app: prowlarr
  template:
    metadata:
      labels:
        app: prowlarr
    spec:
      containers:
      - name: radarr
        image: linuxserver/prowlarr:1.35.1
        env:
          - name: TZ
            value: "Etc/UTC"
        ports:
        - containerPort: 9696
        volumeMounts:
          - name: config
            mountPath: /config
      volumes:
        - name: config
          persistentVolumeClaim:
            claimName: prowlarr-config-pvc
/p;Here is the service configuration.

/c;apiVersion: v1
kind: Service
metadata:
  name: prowlarr-service
spec:
  selector:
    app: prowlarr
  ports:
    - protocol: TCP
      port: 9696
      targetPort: 9696
/p;This is the volume claim and the volume configuration as well in one place.

/c;apiVersion: v1
kind: PersistentVolumeClaim
metadata:
  name: prowlarr-config-pvc
spec:
  storageClassName: local-storage
  accessModes:
    - ReadWriteOnce
  resources:
    requests:
      storage: 1Gi
  volumeName: prowlarr-config-pv
---
apiVersion: v1
kind: PersistentVolume
metadata:
  name: prowlarr-config-pv
spec:
  storageClassName: local-storage
  capacity:
    storage: 1Gi
  accessModes:
    - ReadWriteOnce
  hostPath:
    path: /pool/filesystem/prowlarr/data
/p;And the current ingress setup will look like this with Prowlarr as the new neighbor.

/c;apiVersion: networking.k8s.io/v1
kind: Ingress
metadata:
  name: ingress
  annotations:
    traefik.ingress.kubernetes.io/router.middlewares: default-content-type-options@kubernetescrd
spec:
  rules:
    - host: jellyfin.domain.xyz
      http:
        paths:
          - pathType: Prefix
            path: /
            backend:
              service:
                name: jellyfin-service
                port:
                  number: 8096
    - host: radarr.domain.xyz
      http:
        paths:
          - pathType: Prefix
            path: /
            backend:
              service:
                name: radarr-service
                port:
                  number: 7878
    - host: sonarr.domain.xyz
      http:
        paths:
          - pathType: Prefix
            path: /
            backend:
              service:
                name: sonarr-service
                port:
                  number: 8989
    - host: prowlarr.domain.xyz
      http:
        paths:
          - pathType: Prefix
            path: /
            backend:
              service:
                name: prowlarr-service
                port:
                  number: 9696
/p;Good luck with configuring Prowlarr up. ^^
/h2;Useful fixes for configuration issues
/ul

/s;Nyaa.si results don't show up when searching on Radarr: ;This is a compatiblity issue with nyaa.si, which can be resolved if you had setup the indexers with Prowlarr. In Prowlarr, edit the nyaa.si indexer, and in it's settings turn on 'Improve Radarr compatibility by removing year information from keywords and adding it to Release Titles' option.
//ul

title: Setting up Qbittorrent on k3s in Rocky Linux
intro: This is part 4 of the *arr stack guide
content: /p;PART 1,2,3 OF THIS GUIDE IS MANDATORY

/p;This is the continuation of my quest in building a full *arr stack (Jellyfin, Jellyseerr, Radarr, Sonarr, Prowlarr, Qbittorrent) with k3s (for funsies) in order for my parents not renting out movies from goddamn Telekom.
/p;If you wish to gain some basic understandement on what each of these files are for, then check out the part 1, aka the 'Setting up Jellyfin on k3s in Rocky Linux' article.
/h2;Qbittorrent setup
/p;Qbittorrent's purpose is to actually download the required content via the torrent protocol, which seems pretty important to ig.

/p;In Qbittorrent's case it actually communicates on 2 different ports. Whereas on the 8080 port we can actually observe how the downloads are progressing and configure how Qbittorrent works, the 6881 is the port used for actually downloading and seeding back said content from the interwebz. Other than the config volume, it will logically need a volume to download the files into.

/c;---
apiVersion: apps/v1
kind: Deployment
metadata:
  name: qbittorrent-deployment
  labels:
    app: qbittorrent
spec:
  replicas: 1
  selector:
    matchLabels:
      app: qbittorrent
  template:
    metadata:
      labels:
        app: qbittorrent
    spec:
      containers:
        - name: qbittorrent
          image: linuxserver/qbittorrent:5.1.0
          env:
            - name: TZ
              value: Etc/UTC
            - name: WEBUI_PORT  # This is where we can access qbittorrent, observe the download process and configure it
              value: "8080"
            - name: TORRENTING_PORT  # This is where the torrent download process goes
              value: "6881"
          ports:
            - containerPort: 8080
              protocol: TCP
            - containerPort: 6881
              protocol: UDP
          volumeMounts:
            - name: config
              mountPath: /config
            - name: downloads
              mountPath: /downloads
      volumes:
        - name: config
          persistentVolumeClaim:
            claimName: qbittorrent-config-pvc
        - name: downloads
          persistentVolumeClaim:
            claimName: downloads-pvc

/p;Here is the service configuration, which looks a tiny bit different, cause the ports are named (ex: the 8080 port is regarded as webui). It's not strictily necessary to name these, but where a pod uses more than 1 port, it can be more readable if these ports are named in some way or form.

/c;apiVersion: v1
kind: Service
metadata:
  name: qbittorrent-service
spec:
  selector:
    app: qbittorrent
  ports:
    - name: webui
      protocol: TCP
      port: 8080
      targetPort: 8080
    - name: torrenting
      protocol: UDP
      port: 6881
      targetPort: 6881
  type: LoadBalancer
/p;Here are the volume claims and the volumes

/c;apiVersion: v1
kind: PersistentVolumeClaim
metadata:
  name: qbittorrent-config-pvc
spec:
  storageClassName: local-storage
  accessModes:
    - ReadWriteOnce
  resources:
    requests:
      storage: 1Gi
  volumeName: qbittorrent-config-pv
---
apiVersion: v1
kind: PersistentVolumeClaim
metadata:
  name: qbittorrent-config-pvc
spec:
  storageClassName: local-storage
  accessModes:
    - ReadWriteOnce
  resources:
    requests:
      storage: 1Gi
  volumeName: qbittorrent-config-pv
/p;And also we can't leave out the current ingress configuration.

/c;---
apiVersion: networking.k8s.io/v1
kind: Ingress
metadata:
  name: ingress
  annotations:
    traefik.ingress.kubernetes.io/router.middlewares: default-content-type-options@kubernetescrd
spec:
  rules:
    - host: media.domain.xyz
      http:
        paths:
          - pathType: Prefix
            path: /
            backend:
              service:
                name: jellyfin-service
                port:
                  number: 8096
    - host: radarr.domain.xyz
      http:
        paths:
          - pathType: Prefix
            path: /
            backend:
              service:
                name: radarr-service
                port:
                  number: 7878
    - host: sonarr.domain.xyz
      http:
        paths:
          - pathType: Prefix
            path: /
            backend:
              service:
                name: sonarr-service
                port:
                  number: 8989
    - host: prowlarr.domain.xyz
      http:
        paths:
          - pathType: Prefix
            path: /
            backend:
              service:
                name: prowlarr-service
                port:
                  number: 9696
    - host: qbit.domain.xyz
      http:
        paths:
          - pathType: Prefix
            path: /
            backend:
              service:
                name: qbittorrent-service
                port:
                  number: 8080
    - host: qbitudp.domain.xyz
      http:
        paths:
          - pathType: Prefix
            path: /
            backend:
              service:
                name: qbittorrent-service
                port:
                  number: 6881

/p;Aaaand now you're finally done with starting all the necessary pods to make this *arr ecosystem work. I highly encourage you try also include Jellyseer into the roster, which helps to netflixify this entire process, where you can just request a movie or series, and also see some recommendations.
